Title:
Phylogeny of Cytospora and associated teleomorphs from
Populus spp. and Salix spp. in China, including C. davidiana sp.
nov.
Keywords:
Cytospora canker. Phylogenetic species. Species diversity.
Taxonomy. Populus spp. and Salix spp.
Abstract:
Poplar and willow plantations are becoming more and more
widespread in China to meet the need of national economy. Appearance of
diseases is increasing because of the change of climatic conditions and
other human factors. Species of the genus Cytospora spp. and associated
teleomorphs are the most common pathogens on both poplar and willow.
They cause serious economic losses for the wood production and
ecological benefit. The aim of this study was to identify the Cytospora
and associated teleomorphs species occuring on Populus spp. and Salix
spp. in China. Morphology and phylogenetic inferences based on internal
transcribed spacer region (ITS1, 5.8S rDNA and ITS2) and partial
Î²-tubulin gene regions showed that 6 species were recognized among the
studied collections. One species is described as C. davidiana sp.nov.
One of them represents new report from China: C. kantschavelii. In
addition, Four of them correspond with the previous morphology-based
taxa: C. chrysosperma (teleomorph V. sordida), C. translucens
(teleomorph L. translucens), C. fugax (teleomorph V. salicina), and C.
atrocirrhata, and remaining one phylogenetic species Cytospora sp.1 was
not described due to the paucity of the materials. The placement of
Cytospora spp. and relative teleomorphs were well resolved by the
morphological and molecular phylogeny. The further effort for a
continued sampling collection and multi-gene loci are needed to better
understand their diversity and distribution.
